title-group.article-title: The expatriate-creativity hypothesis: A longitudinal field test

contrib.aff: University of Technology Sydney, Australia, Anthony.Fee@uts.edu.au

author-notes.corresp: Sidney J Gray, Department of International Business, University of Sydney, Sydney, NSW 2006, Australia. Email: sid.gray@sydney.edu.au

abstract.p: While prior research suggests that the cognitive changes triggered by cross-cultural experiences can enhance an individual’s creative-thinking abilities, this is yet to be verified through empirical field research. We draw on schema theory, and the principle of psychological dissonance experienced during cultural adaptation, to argue that expatriates undergo wholesale cognitive changes that can lead to enhanced creative-thinking abilities. We test this hypothesis by measuring changes in the creative-thinking abilities of a sample of expatriates over the first 12 months of their placement. When compared with a control group of non-expatriates, the expatriates showed significant increases in overall creative-thinking abilities and cognitive flexibility, although not originality, elaboration, or ideational fluency.

body.p: The ongoing process of globalization continues to dismantle barriers that previously separated cultures, and in the process has created societies and organizations brimming with people from different cultural backgrounds. Research into the culturally diverse nature of organizations has tended to emphasize the advantages and challenges of ‘managing’ a workforce or team comprising members from diverse backgrounds (e.g. Tran et al., 2011; Van Laer and Janssens, 2011), while often overlooking the multiple forms of diversity that exist within individual workers. A growing literature stream has begun to highlight the benefit to organizations (and individuals) of the unique perspectives, knowledge, and abilities of bi- and multi-cultural staff, and of staff with diverse cross-cultural experiences (e.g. Benet-Martínez et al., 2006; Tadmor and Tetlock, 2006). For organizations, attracting, developing and retaining such employees may be critical to success in a globalized, knowledge economy (Harvey and Moeller, 2009).

At the forefront of this phenomenon are multinational organizations from the corporate, government, and non-government sectors. As well as comprising staff and leaders from diverse cultural backgrounds, these organizations play an active role in global ‘brain circulation’ through recruiting and expatriating staff to and from different parts of the world, and so are increasingly staffed by individuals possessing a breadth of cross-cultural experiences, languages and identities (Taylor and Osland, 2003). Within this context, there is a need to understand how these individuals have been shaped by their multicultural experiences, and how latent capabilities that emerge from these experiences might be utilized (e.g. Osland et al., 2006).

In this article, we examine the hypothesis that the processes of cognitive change that expatriates undergo whilst adapting to a new culture can lead to them becoming more creative thinkers. Expatriates, defined as people who spend a period of time living and working in a foreign country, confront myriad novel, ambiguous, and challenging situations that disrupt their habitual routines. In response, they are forced to internalize a series of cognitive adjustments as a means of coping in the new environment. These adjustments can include fundamental reshaping of how they see the world, resulting in changes that are permanent – even transformational (e.g. Osland, 2001). One outcome of these, we suggest, is the loosening of one-dimensional routines and attitudes, and the creation of a more flexible, more creative mindset.

The article contains three sections. Firstly, we review extant literature and outline the theoretical basis for the study. From this, the study’s hypotheses are drawn. Next, we detail the research methods and findings of the study. Finally, the results are discussed in relation to their practical and theoretical implications for organizations and expatriates alike.

sec.title: Creativity and creative development
sec.p: Creativity, defined broadly as the ability to produce ideas that are both novel and relevant (e.g. Amabile, 1996), has been called ‘the ultimate economic resource’ (Florida, 2004: xiii). It is the cornerstone of knowledge creation and innovation, and is increasingly recognized as critical to the long-term success of individual careers, firms, and even nations (e.g. Benedek et al., 2006). While research has begun to unearth a range of knowledge, skills, behaviors, and attitudes that can contribute towards individual creativity, central among these are the various creative-thinking abilities – cognitive processing abilities that enable the individual to produce creative ideas (e.g. Ward et al., 1999). Unlike convergent thinking, which focuses on identifying single solutions to problems, creative thinking produces multiple and varied responses. It is central to creativity; indeed, most tests measuring individual creativity are, in fact, creative-thinking tests (see, for example, Runco, 2007).

In general, creative thinkers are those who possess four related abilities that are critical to creativity in any domain (e.g. Guilford, 1959; Torrance, 1966). Firstly, their cognitive structures allow them to produce a large number of ideas that are relevant to the requirements of the problem or task at hand. This ideational fluency involves the efficient and rapid retrieval of information and ideas from within one’s cognitive frameworks, the generation of logical possibilities or alternatives, and the application of these to new situations (Guilford, 1967b). Such abilities are frequently the focus of structured ‘creativity’ training interventions through the teaching of creative heuristics like brainstorming or ‘what if’ scenarios (e.g. Benedek et al., 2006). Secondly, creative individuals are able to produce ideas that are uncommon, unexpected, or unusual (originality). This originality is generally operationalized as the production of ideas that are rare (i.e., statistically less common than the norm; e.g. Torrance, 1966), and thus relates to the quality of ideas being developed, rather than the quantity. Thirdly, creative individuals also have the ability to embellish their ideas with detail and complexity. This elaboration is important in developing the quality of an idea from its often vague and generalized origins to a more useable ‘finished product.’ As such, it involves developing and communicating the operational specifications and implications that can contribute to both the originality and relevance of an idea by making it more easily understood, or more readily accepted by users. Finally, creative people are cognitively flexible. Cognitive flexibility involves being able to re-frame problems or examine situations in different ways. It assists creative output by enabling the individual to overcome mental blockages or ‘functional fixidity’ through avoiding well-used patterns of behavior (Smith and Blankenship, 1991), and so results in a variety of possible interpretations that cover a problem from multiple perspectives.

In combination, these four components: cognitive flexibility, ideational fluency, elaboration, and originality, are the building blocks of creative thinking. They enable cognitive pathways to be explored and information to be processed in ways that provide the ‘something extra’ (Amabile, 1996: 87) that distinguish technically competent responses from truly creative ones.

While studies have reported that formal teaching interventions can increase particular creative-thinking abilities in adults (e.g. Puccio et al., 2006), only recently have researchers begun examining whether creative-thinking abilities can be developed ‘informally’, outside structured training interventions. The core of this has been work undertaken by Leung, Maddux and colleagues (e.g. Leung et al., 2008; Maddux and Galinsky, 2009). Working primarily with students, they have conducted a barrage of cross-sectional studies examining the impact of simulated and (past) authentic multicultural experiences on subjects’ creative output on particular problem-solving and/or divergent-thinking tasks. While these studies are limited to correlational methods or temporary experimental manipulations, they consistently report an association between prior experience living abroad and more creative responses. However, although this impressive line of investigation has demonstrated an association between cross-cultural experiences and greater creativity, and via the experimental work suggests causal linkages under certain conditions, research to date has relied on cross-sectional studies in controlled laboratory settings. Accordingly, the relationship between one’s cross-cultural experience and creative-thinking abilities remains unconfirmed by real-world tests.

sec.title: Expatriation and cultural adaptation
sec.p: While ‘corporate’ expatriates within multinational firms remain the focus of expatriate researchers (Bonache et al., 2001), a broader view of expatriation is emerging, in recognition that expatriates in the government and non-government sectors are equally critical to the success of their organizations, and confront similar challenges and opportunities to those in the corporate sector (Lambell et al., 2008). One such challenge faced by all expatriates is that of adapting to the host culture. Researchers have documented a range of individual antecedents as well as work and non-work environmental inputs that can influence cultural adaptation outcomes (e.g. Bhaskar-Shrinivas et al., 2005). Theoretical approaches to understanding cultural adaptation are premised on equilibrium models, which view it as a process triggered by the need to achieve harmony between individuals’ perceptual frames of reference, their behavior, and their socio-cultural environments (e.g. Ward et al., 2001). From this perspective, adaptation is a response to the cognitive tension accompanying the psychological ‘imbalance’ created by the new environment (Torbiörn, 1982).

One line of research examining adaptation patterns and consequences focuses on the psychological troughs and peaks that expatriates experience when adjusting to a new culture (e.g. Berry, 2006). These temporal models show that adaptation first requires a breakdown of existing mental maps, a process caused by the stripping away of familiar touchstones and reference points that normally guide behavior and identity. This is followed by a period of cognitive transformation during which expatriates reconfigure their cognitive frames of reference in order to develop the wherewithal to cope in the new surroundings (e.g. Kim, 1988).

The psychological outcomes of cultural adaptation are double-edged, involving both short-term pain, like anxiety, stress, and frustration (e.g. Oberg, 1960), and long-term gain – for instance, improved cultural-awareness and problem-solving skills (e.g. Anderson, 1994; Kim, 2001). Doidge (2008: 299) calls living in a foreign culture ‘an unending, brutal workout for the adult brain’ that forces wholesale cognitive rewiring and promotes new neural connections. In the following section we outline a tentative theoretical framework that links these cognitive changes to the processes of cultural adaptation.

sec.title: Theoretical framework
sec.p: Our cognitive schemas provide the template through which we view the world and process information (Weick et al., 2004). These ‘mental maps’, developed through experiences in our home culture, lack the interpretive ballast to handle the demanding situations encountered in a new cultural environment, where misunderstandings, misattributions, and mistakes are common experiences (Selmer, 2005). These experiences activate two processes (e.g. Kim, 2001): one of deculturation (relinquishing and adjusting aspects of one’s existing cognitive databank), and another of acculturation (building new schemas by taking on elements of the new culture). We propose that each contributes in different ways to individual creative-thinking abilities. Below we outline our basis for this, together with related hypotheses.

sec.title: Deculturation
sec.p: In the early stages of being in a new culture, expatriates’ perceptions are dictated by home-culture mental maps, which operate within a limited range of habitual cognitive frames (Weick, 1979). While effective in the ‘equilibrium’ of a single culture, these schemas are inadequate to process situations in the new cultural surrounds (Shaw, 1990). Thus, a common response to the disorientation of a new culture is to surrender out-dated, one-dimensional routines and processes (e.g. Adler, 1975; Anderson, 1994; Kim, 2001). While some home-culture scripts may be retained, or even affirmed (e.g. Bond and Yang, 1982), in general ethnocentric schemas, which are least flexible and integrated (i.e. rigid, one-dimensional), are most readily relinquished because they provide the least value in the host culture (Endicott et al., 2003); Kim (2003: 261) refers to this process as ‘unlearning … old cultural habits’. By way of example, an American expatriate posted to India will quickly learn that rigid, one-dimensional ways of interpreting communication cues (e.g. nodding one’s head always means ‘yes’), or resolving interpersonal conflict (e.g. discussing a problem is always the best solution), are unlikely to succeed and so must, at least temporarily, be abandoned.

Surrendering habitual schemas leads to short-term pain through loss of confidence and identity (e.g. Ward et al., 2001). However, it forces expatriates to confront the possibility that multiple interpretations exist, and thus to broaden the range of schemas they activate. In order to understand situations and make attributions, they must explore new connections between categories of knowledge (Leung and Chiu, 2008). The result, we suggest, is that expatriates process situations more flexibly, and become adept at recognizing multiple meanings, resolving internal discrepancies, and bringing competing ideas together (Smith and Blankenship, 1991). Cognitively flexible people have low levels of functional fixedness, and so are able to apply knowledge in a variety of contexts (Plucker and Runco, 1999). The most extreme outcome of this, achieved by truly bi- or multi-cultural individuals, is the flexibility to frame-switch between perspectives effortlessly (Hong et al., 2000). Accordingly, we hypothesize that:
Hypothesis 1: Expatriates undertaking expatriate assignments will show a significant increase in cognitive flexibility, when compared with non-expatriates.

The second consequence of the deculturation process is that expatriates can no longer rely on instinctive information processing. Researchers have long recognized the constraints of subconscious, habitual perception to the production of creative responses (e.g. Ford, 1996). This is particularly common in the familiar surrounds of one’s own culture, where environmental cues can be recognized, processed, and categorized with great speed and efficiency using existing schemas. In contrast, behavioral episodes that cannot be categorized automatically must be processed in a more active or mindful way (Louis and Sutton, 1991; Shaw, 1990). Thomas and Inkson (2003: 40) refer to this as ‘switching off (one’s) cultural cruise control.’ While active information processing requires effort and energy, it stifles habitual thought patterns (Louis and Sutton, 1991). Less constrained by initial conventional responses, expatriates develop the ability to suspend judgment and move more fluidly to alternative ‘hypothesis’ responses rather than ineffective, habitual responses. As Koestler (1963: 333) notes in his classic treatise of creativity, ‘The mind in labor is liberated from the tyranny of rigid, over-precise schemata: it is enabled to unlearn and acquire … a greater fluidity of thought.’ This ideational fluency (Mednick, 1962) is critical to creative problem-solving because it enables the production of an array of (potential) alternative options. Thus, our second hypothesis is:
Hypothesis 2: Expatriates undertaking expatriate assignments will show a significant increase in ideational fluency, when compared with non-expatriates.

One prominent set of home-culture mental maps that undergo transformation relate to the verbal and non-verbal codes through which we communicate. Communicating across cultural boundaries is ‘at the heart of cross-cultural adaptation’ (Kim, 1988: 59). It requires developing shared meaning with others whose cognitive frames may differ sharply from one’s own (Gudykunst and Kim, 1992). In the absence of shared assumptions and intent, effective cross-cultural communication – irrespective of the common language/s being used – necessitates great cognitive attention to the encoding and decoding of messages during interactions, and adjustments to the way in which messages are transmitted and received (Kassis-Henderson, 2005). This includes surrendering the use of ‘restricted’ (or shorthand) communication, which enables efficient in-group communication, for the use of more ‘elaborated codes’ that require greater planning and explicitness (Bernstein, 1966). For instance, articulatory clues, both verbal and non-verbal, must be expanded, and vocabulary and syntactic selection more highly elaborated. Among the approaches commonly used are supplementing verbal with non-verbal cues, communicating intentions behind a message, using signposting and labeling language more frequently, and being attuned to specific feedback (e.g. Comfort and Franklin, 2010; Kassis-Henderson, 2005). This use of stronger elaboration codes in cross-cultural interactions may be especially high among expatriates from individualistic societies (Gudykunst and Kim, 2003), who seek greater verbal clarity from communication.

The relationship between language and cognition, while contested, has a long history (e.g. Sapir, 1985). It is generally agreed that repeated communication patterns have a strong influence on cognition in a range of domains (Conway and Schaller, 2007), a view supported via recent experimental studies using brain imaging technology (Franklin et al., 2008). Elaboration, while the least studied of the four creative-thinking abilities, is seen primarily as a communication ability that involves giving ‘flesh and skin to the skeleton (of an idea) by adding detailed information’ (Guilford, 1967a: 104). Torrance (1967) is one who has argued that encouraging the use of verbal elaboration skills can help learners to develop elaboration abilities necessary to support creative thinking. For these reasons, on balance, we hypothesize:
Hypothesis 3: Expatriates undertaking expatriate assignments will show a significant increase in elaboration, when compared with non-expatriates.

sec.title: Acculturation
sec.p:
As well as forcing changes to the composition and use of one’s existing schema, the adaptation process requires expatriates to create new cognitive frames (Kim, 2001). This occurs later in the adaptation process, as the expatriate begins to recognize and value differences within the new culture, and to integrate these with their current worldview (Adler, 1975). Several authors have argued that the diverse range of people, ideas, and problems that expatriates confront are conducive to developing original ideas (e.g. Leung and Chiu, 2008), and cross-sectional studies with expatriates and immigrants have shown that as they acculturate they develop new schemas that integrate different worldviews (e.g. Kim, 1988; Tadmor and Tetlock, 2006). In other words, rather than simply assimilating host-culture approaches within existing schemas, the process of integrating the new experiences causes fundamental changes to expatriates’ cognitive structures. This is, in effect, a process of forced learning that is provoked by the new socio-cultural milieu; as Berns (2008: 199) notes, ‘(t)he brain is lazy’:
It only changes when it has to. And the conditions that consistently force the brain to rewire itself are when it confronts something novel.

In general, this schema creation (acculturation) and integration is only possible once the expatriate recognizes the limitations of home-culture scripts. At this stage, novel stimuli from the environment are acknowledged as being useful, and so noticed and retained, rather than screened out by perceptual biases that may be present earlier in the adaptation process (Black and Mendenhall, 1991). Once integrated, we argue, these new schemas provide the foundation to enable expatriates to produce original responses that capitalize on both home- and host-culture frames (Rothenberg, 1976). Such ideas may include extensions or adaptations of either home- or host-culture perspectives, or ‘hybrid’ responses or analogies that are original in their own right and which spring from combining the two perspectives. Lynton and Thøgersen (2006: 172, 179), for instance, have recently reported that expatriates working with Chinese host-culture nationals began to change their ‘analytical thought patterns’ and develop ‘new cognitive styles’ that incorporate eastern and western patterns of thought. This integration of different perspectives enables the production of ideas that are unique, and thus our fourth hypothesis is:
Hypothesis 4: Expatriates undertaking expatriate assignments will show a significant increase in originality, when compared with non-expatriates.

Collectively, the arguments and research presented above suggest that cultural adaptation can lead expatriates to develop the four building blocks of creative thinking. Thus we expect that, ceteris paribus, these changes would lead to an improvement in expatriates’ overall creative-thinking abilities. For this reason, our final hypothesis is:
Hypothesis 5: Expatriates undertaking expatriate assignments will show a significant increase in overall creative-thinking abilities, when compared with non-expatriates.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: To examine these hypotheses, our study employed a pretest–post-test longitudinal panel design with two non-equivalent groups: a group of expatriates, and a ‘control’ group of non-expatriates. All participants were native speakers of English. Data were collected via a commonly used psychometric test administered at pre-departure (T 1) and again 12 months later (T2) – a duration deemed sufficient to prevent the practice effect or pre-test sensitization (Gay, 1996). Because random allocation to groups was not possible, statistical methods were used to control for any inter-group differences at pre-departure (Gay, 1996). Four additional variables that research suggests may moderate the effect of expatriation on creativity were controlled for:

list-item.p: Age: While creative-thinking abilities are generally believed to remain stable in adulthood, research shows that cognitive maturation or decline can alter creative performance (e.g. Jaquish and Ripple, 1981; Torrance, 1968);
Profession: Although participants came from a range of occupations, creative behavior, and hence development, may differ according to the requirements of the work role (Unsworth et al., 2005);
Role transition: Novelty associated with a major change in work role may stimulate more controlled information processing (Louis and Sutton, 1991), and so moderate post-test scores; and
Previous international experience: The research of Leung et al. (2008) shows that past international experience may influence baseline measures and thus the extent of change observed.

sec.title: Expatriate group
sec.p: The purposive sample comprises a rarely studied sub-sector of the expatriate community – professionals working in international aid and development, hereafter referred to as expatriate development professionals (EDPs). EDPs are highly skilled, professional expatriates working in the ‘third sector’ of NGOs and operating within communities in least developed countries. They work in a range of professions, notably health, education, and governance, although increasingly in business and management (Cook and Jackson, 2006). The objectives of EDPs are linked to the broader landscape of international development, which aims to help individuals, organizations and communities become self-reliant (e.g. Remenyi, 2004). In our study, EDPs were recruited through Australian Volunteers International (AVI), a not-for-profit organization that has managed almost 8000 self-initiated EDP placements over a 50-year period.

Three theoretical factors determined this choice of sample. Firstly, a number of researchers have called for the use of expatriate samples beyond the ‘headquarters-to-subsidiary management transfer’ paradigm (Harvey and Moeller, 2009: 279), and which better reflect the multifarious reality of contemporary global workers (Inkson et al., 1997). Moreover, unlike many corporate expatriates, the objective of the EDPs’ role focuses on the development of the organization (and community) with which they work, rather than their own personal development. This was important because research has shown that expatriates assigned for ‘professional development’ reasons are more likely to report personal change than those expatriated for other reasons (Shay and Baack, 2004). Thirdly, while their placements were managed by AVI, all participants were employed in, and reported to, a diverse number of host-culture organizations and communities in a total of 18 different countries. Consequently, the sample enabled the study to control for extraneous influences from the immediate work environment, thus enhancing generalizability.

The expatriate group comprised a diverse sample of 86 Australian and New Zealand EDPs. Subjects came from a variety of professions, including managers, consultants, accountants, lawyers, doctors, social workers, educators, and IT experts; 38 percent were male, while 94 percent held formal post-school qualifications. Subjects’ age at pre-departure ranged from 20 to 68 years (mean = 41.5, SD = 13.3). The expatriates undertook assignments in 18 different countries in Asia (e.g. Timor Leste, China, Indonesia, Thailand), the Pacific (e.g. Papua New Guinea, Kiribati, Solomon Islands), and Africa (e.g. Malawi, Swaziland, South Africa). Just over three-quarters (76%) had previous international work experience.

sec.title: Control group
sec.p: Sampling criteria for the control group included two conditions: (a) undertaking full-time work in domestic settings, and (b) attending the pre-departure briefing. The latter was considered important to remove the potential that the briefing would influence the dependent variable. The control group of 20 professionals comprised volunteers who were unable to accept their assignment owing to circumstances beyond their control (no work visa, deterioration of security in the host country, family health), as well as current and former AVI staff who had attended the same briefing as part of their orientation to the organization. Like the expatriate group, they came from a variety of professions. Ages ranged from 27 to 68 years (mean = 37.6, SD = 9.6). Males comprised 45 percent of this group, while 80 percent held formal post-school qualifications. Seventy percent had prior international work experience.

sec.title: Sample attrition
sec.p: In longitudinal research, participant withdrawal can reduce the sample size and confound the measurement of change (de Vaus, 2002). While steps were taken to limit attrition (e.g. seeking alternative contact details), several participants were forced to or chose to withdraw during the study. The final sample comprised 54 expatriates and 15 non-expatriates, representing an overall attrition rate of 35 percent. The major contributor to attrition of expatriates was political or military upheaval in host countries (one-third of all withdrawing expatriates). For others, the most common explanations were early return (i.e. placement ‘failure’ or illness), unreliable communication in the host country, or too busy. The rate of attrition compares favorably with other longitudinal studies, even in domestic contexts, where withdrawal rates above 50 percent have been reported (e.g. Hechanova-Alampay et al., 2002). The final sample sizes were sufficiently large for statistical purposes. They meet the minimum suggested for ‘natural experiment’ studies (Gay, 1996), are comparable with other recent longitudinal studies of expatriates (e.g. Suutari and Brewster, 2003), and were as large as was possible, or likely possible, under constrained ‘real-world’ circumstances, obtained through the cooperation of AVI. Independent t-tests revealed no significant differences between the two samples on main demographic variables.1

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: All instruments, and the protocols involved in administering them, were administered in the English language, and were pilot tested with postgraduate students (n = 48) prior to being used.

sec.title: Dependent variables
sec.p: While at least 250 instruments exist that aim or claim to provide objective measures of creative-thinking abilities (Cropley, 2000), this study used an identical before-and-after psychometric test of creative-thinking ability, the highly regarded Torrance Test of Creative Thinking (TTCT) (Torrance, 1966). An abbreviated form of the TTCT developed specifically for adults (Goff and Torrance, 2002), the Abbreviated Torrance Test for Adults (ATTA), was used. The test measures all four cognitive abilities associated with creative thinking in adults (Goff and Torrance, 2002): ideational fluency, originality, cognitive flexibility and elaboration, as well as a range of creativity indicators, like resistance to premature closure, and conceptual incongruity. The subjects’ responses are coded using detailed guidelines to produce a numeric score for each sub-scale, and an overall creativity index. Results have been shown to be fair in terms of race and gender across language, socioeconomic and cultural boundaries (Kim et al., 2006; Torrance, 1987). For instance, originality scores are those that are statistically infrequent based on responses drawn across different cultural and socio-economic groups, and so results are not distorted by culturally different, rather than truly original, responses.

Multiple studies and meta-studies across a 40-year period have demonstrated the test’s predictive and concurrent validity, internal consistency, and inter-rater and test–retest reliability (see, for example, Cramond et al., 2005; Goff and Torrance, 2002; Kabanoff and Bottger, 1991). Importantly, the test does not discriminate creativity in one field from another (Hocevar, 1981). This was a critical determinant because our hypotheses relate to generic creative-thinking abilities, rather than domain-specific knowledge and behavioral skills. Earlier studies have shown that the creative requirement of a work role can influence creative output in relation to the specific work domain (Unsworth et al., 2005). Thus, a domain-neutral test like the ATTA was able to capture most directly the type of (cognitive) changes being hypothesized.

The ATTA comes with detailed protocols to ensure administration is standardized (Goff and Torrance, 2002), including verbatim instructions and time limits. These protocols were used to administer the test at pre-departure briefings (T1). Most participants were still on assignment at T2, and so all post-tests, including the control groups’, used independent administrators. Participants were posted a separate sealed envelope containing a copy of the test booklet, the written administration protocols and specific instructions, and asked to give the envelope to an independent person to administer the test. Participants were aware of this requirement prior to agreeing to participate in the study. All administrators completed and signed a form confirming their role in administering the test, and returned the tests to the researchers. On these forms, all administrators confirmed that no problems were experienced.

Professional expert coders, blind to the hypotheses, were contracted to score completed tests. These trained and experienced coders were employed by Scholastic Testing Service in the United States, the firm which produces and oversees the administration of the TTCT/ATTA tests globally. All test responses were coded for anonymity prior to being scored. Subjects’ scores in the cognitive flexibility (Hypothesis 1), ideational fluency (Hypothesis 2), elaboration (Hypothesis 3), and originality (Hypothesis 4) sub-scales, as well as overall Creativity Index (Hypothesis 5), were used as dependent variables in hypothesis testing. In line with the hypotheses, the Creativity Index used to test Hypothesis 5 is not independent of the measures for Hypotheses 1–4; rather, it is a composite measure that includes cognitive flexibility, ideational fluency, elaboration, and originality as sub-scales.

sec.title: Control variables
sec.p: A brief survey administered at pre-departure collected basic demographic and employment data, including age (in years) and previous international experience (duration in years). Subjects’ occupation was categorized using the internationally recognized Australian and New Zealand Standard Classification of Occupations (ANZSCO) (ABS/SNZ, 2006). As a measure of role transition, subjects were asked ‘What is your current or most recent position (job title and role)?’. This was then compared with the position and work role that the subject undertook during the study period (‘What is your position over the next 12 months (job title and role)?’). Using the ANZSCO classifications, responses were coded according to whether subjects’ placement involved a change of role (e.g. from a technical role to a teaching or managerial role), or whether it was unchanged (0 = no change; 1 = change).2

sec.title: Comparison with withdrawing participants
sec.p: A series of post-hoc one-way analyses of variance (ANOVA) were conducted on pre-departure scores for all dependent variables. These compared: (a) participants withdrawing from the study (n = 37) with those completing both data waves (n = 69), irrespective of the reason for withdrawal or the group (i.e. expatriate/control); (b) expatriates forced to withdraw owing to evacuation (n = 14) with those who withdrew for other or unspecified reasons (n = 18); and (c) (i) expatriates completing the study (n = 54), (ii) expatriates who withdrew (n = 32), (iii) control group members completing the study (n = 15), and (iv) control group members who withdrew (n = 5). Normality tests on each group of data were satisfactory. No significant differences were found between subjects completing final tests and those who withdrew.3 The final sample was therefore deemed representative of the initial sample for the purposes of the subsequent analysis.

sec.title: Hypotheses testing
sec.p: Testing the hypotheses involved comparing pre-test to post-test changes in the two groups’ scores on each of the dependent variables: cognitive flexibility (Hypothesis 1), ideational fluency (Hypothesis 2), elaboration (Hypothesis 3), originality (Hypothesis 4), and creativity index (Hypothesis 5).

First, a series of separate split plot analysis of variance tests (SPANOVA) were performed for each dependent variable using a single within-subject factor of time (pre/post), and a single between-subject grouping factor (expatriate/control). The SPANOVA method is a variation of the parametric statistical procedure, analysis of variance, which tests differences between groups of people, and is commonly used in experimental studies (Cronbach, 1957). By enabling both between-group and repeat-measures variables in the analysis, it can measure and compare the impact of an ‘intervention’ on different groups over the period of time. The method controls for any differences between the two groups’ scores at pre-departure, and so overcomes problems associated with subjects not being randomly allocated to groups.

In all analyses, the tests of between-subject effects were non-significant, indicating no direct effect of variables on the ATTA scores themselves. Table 2 shows the results of the SPANOVA analyses, reporting the effects of covariates and the expatriate intervention on the change in scores of each dependent variable.

caption.p: Split plot analyses of variance (SPANOVA) comparing changes in scores pre- and post-expatriate assignment across expatriate group and control group: tests of within-subjects effects

fn.p: Main effects on the change in creativity score are reported.

sec.p: As the Table shows, after controlling for moderating variables, a significant positive effect in respect of the expatriate assignment over time was found for cognitive flexibility (F(1, 63) = 5.45, p = .02) and the creativity index (F(1, 63) = 6.09, p = .01). Using the F-ratios to calculate an effect size in the form of a Pearson correlation coefficient, r, the expatriate assignment intervention represents moderate effect sizes of .28 and .30, respectively. However, the interaction effects for ideational fluency (F(1, 63) = .52, p = .47, r = .09), elaboration (F(1, 63) = .29, p = .59, r = .07), and originality (F(1, 63) = 1.69, p = .20, r = .16) were not significant. Thus, the SPANOVA analyses give support to Hypothesis 1 and Hypothesis 5 only.

Next, in order to triangulate results, dependent means t-tests examined whether the change in the expatriate group’s scores were, in their own right, statistically significant (i.e., regardless of changes in the control group’s scores). Again, the results showed that the expatriates’ pre-post scores increased significantly for both cognitive flexibility (t(53) = 4.13, p < .001, 2-tailed) and the creativity index (t(53) = 3.95, p < .001, 2-tailed), but not originality (t(53) = .16, p = .87, 2-tailed). However, the t-test did show a significant rise in expatriates’ pre-post ideational fluency scores (t(53) = 2.13, p = .03, 2-tailed), while the rise in elaboration was significant at the p < .1 level (t(53) = −1.87, p = .07, 2-tailed). Using an equation described by Rosenthal (1991), the increase in expatriates’ scores represent moderate to strong effects of r = .49 (creativity index), r = .48 (cognitive flexibility), r = .28 (ideational fluency), and r = .25 (elaboration). The changes in the control group’s scores were non-significant for all tests.

Collectively, the results unanimously support Hypothesis 1 and Hypothesis 5 (significant increases in cognitive flexibility and overall creative thinking). However, contrary to our predictions, expatriates did not show an increase in originality (Hypothesis 4). While expatriates’ ideational fluency and elaboration levels rose across the study period, this increase was not significant when compared to the changes in the control group’s score, and so there is insufficient evidence to support Hypothesis 2 or Hypothesis 3 (significant increases in ideational fluency and elaboration, respectively).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This longitudinal field study examined whether, and to what extent, an expatriate assignment could contribute positively toward expatriates’ creative-thinking abilities (as measured by pretest–post-test changes in scores of the Abbreviated Torrance Test for Adults). The results show that expatriates, in general, increased their overall creative-thinking abilities (Hypothesis 5), and that the major – indeed, the sole significant – contributor to this was an increase in cognitive flexibility (Hypothesis 1). Both these increases were statistically significant in their own right (i.e. pretest–post-test comparison), and when compared with a control group of non-expatriates. However, the belief that an expatriate assignment can contribute significantly to the other building blocks of creative thinking is unsupported. In short, our data show that, rather than expatriation contributing to the full range of abilities that can make an individual a better creative thinker, its effect occurs primarily through enhanced cognitive flexibility.

The effect sizes for the increase in cognitive flexibility and overall creative thinking were moderate to strong, ranging from r = .28 to .49. To our knowledge, no longitudinal panel studies have previously quantified ‘natural’ changes in creative-thinking abilities. However, evaluations of formal training interventions – often criticized for producing post-measures that are inflated by confirmation bias, ‘training to criterion’, and demand characteristics (e.g. Parloff and Handlon, 1964) – have been conducted. For instance, Scott et al. (2004) carried out a meta-analysis of 70 pretest–post-test studies reporting the impact of a variety of different creativity training programs. While different measures were used, making cross-study comparisons difficult, the authors report that for studies utilizing subjects over the age of 14, the average overall effect size was Δ = .59 (SE = .13). In a meta-analysis of 46 studies that all used the TTCT to measure the impact of creativity training, most with school-aged subjects, Rose and Lin (1984) found that formal training accounted for 22 percent of the variance in performance. Both these averages represent effect sizes not dissimilar to the current study. Other longitudinal panel studies using the TTCT to measure the impact of structured training interventions with adults have reported calculable effect sizes ranging from .37 to .42 (e.g. Clapham, 1997; Goff, 1992). In summary, the effects we observed on cognitive flexibility and overall creative thinking are not dissimilar to those achieved by structured creativity training initiatives.

From the perspective of the theoretical model described above, the results suggest that it is the deculturation stage of adaptation, during which the expatriate struggles to achieve equilibrium by challenging and manipulating existing schemas, that has the major impact on expatriates’ creative development, rather than the schema-building process of acculturation. On this point, the results give tentative support for the phased framework of cognitive change that we introduce. Hypotheses 1–4 relate chronologically to phases of adaptation, and the change occurring ‘earliest’ in the adaptation process showed the strongest effect (Hypothesis 1 – cognitive flexibility), with mixed support for Hypothesis 2 (fluency) and Hypothesis 3 (elaboration), and none for Hypothesis 4 (originality). Thus, one explanation for the absence of support for Hypothesis 4 is that the benefits of the acculturation stage to one’s originality may take longer than the time allowed in our study. While most researchers suggest that sojourners adapt fully within the first 12 months (e.g. Ward et al., 2001), it is possible that the subjects had not adapted sufficiently to integrate the cultural learning fully in ways that facilitated responses that were original or fully elaborated (Bhaskar-Shrinivas et al., 2005). Alternatively, full integration may require a form of post-adjustment that might not take place until after repatriation to the home country. If this is the case, study periods longer than the current 12-month duration and/or which capture post-repatriation data may be required for any originality gains to be apparent.

On a related issue, while the average pre-departure scores of all five dependent variables were higher for subjects with prior international experience than those with no prior experience, these differences were not significant. In other words, prior international experience did not predict pre-departure scores on any of the five scales we report for either group, or for the full sample. Therefore, it is possible that the benefits from acculturation may, in fact, be reversed as the individual re-acculturates to the home culture. Alternatively, it may be that the creative-thinking abilities developed during the prior international assignments may not have been activated recently and so remained dormant at pre-departure (e.g. Shaw, 1990); activating these may have required a form of cognitive priming (see Hong et al., 2000). Given this finding, we suggest that further longitudinal studies tracking repatriates after their return from an international assignment might be fruitful.

sec.title: Theoretical implications and limitations
sec.p: While earlier studies have shown a correlation and suggested links between expatriation and changes in creative-thinking ability, the empirical results presented here provide tentative support for this research, which until now has been confined to laboratory-based, cross-sectional designs. Moreover, while longitudinal studies have been used to understand elements of the expatriate experience (e.g. Suutari and Brewster, 2003), such studies are rare (Harrison et al., 2004), and there exists a notable absence of studies employing pretest–post-test panel designs, despite these being the most conclusive measure of intra-individual change across time. Thus, this study provides arguably the most direct empirical test to date of the expatriate-creativity hypothesis. In doing so, we believe that the findings provide some welcome nuance. It has long been claimed, and often assumed, that cross-cultural experiences make expatriates more creative. While our results support this, they do suggest that a more accurate link might exist between the challenges of deculturation and cognitive flexibility, which is recognized as the creative-thinking ability most sensitive to experience and change (Runco and Charles, 1997). Given that cognitive flexibility is a skill frequently associated with global leadership (Osland et al., 2006), the findings offer support for the effectiveness of expatriate assignments for developing valuable capabilities. At the same time, the results challenge two existing assumptions within expatriate research: firstly, that creative-thinking ability is an issue of expatriate selection rather than development (e.g. Harvey and Novicevic, 2002), and, secondly, that fundamental personal change is confined to expatriates on developmental assignments (Shay and Baack, 2004).

Before addressing the practical implications of the findings, several caveats should be considered in interpreting the results. The TTCT/ATTA, while the most widely used and validated test of creativity, measures creative-thinking ability, rather than creative output. As discussed earlier, this was an important determinant in our choosing to use it. However, while the ATTA’s predictive validity is strong (e.g. Plucker, 1999), the relationship between the expatriates’ enhanced cognitive flexibility and their work output is unclear. Secondly, we theorize that the changes we observed emerge from the expatriates’ adjustment to their new cultural environment. However, culture operates at multiple levels, and so which cultural environment remains unclear. The expatriates crossed multiple cultural boundaries, including organization, profession, level of development, and nation, and while the variety of national and organizational settings of the sample help control for many extraneous variables, the influence of factors like leadership style or the workplace environment (e.g. Wang and Rode, 2010) cannot be discounted. Similarly, while we controlled for a range of variables shown to moderate creative-thinking abilities, other personal and acquired antecedents like personality, motivations, learning orientation, or cultural upbringing (e.g. Caligiuri, 2000; Leung and Chiu, 2008) may have influenced the effects noticed. Thus, we suggest that the study be viewed as an initial investigation that should be followed by a more fine-grained analysis of the impact of various antecedents and environments.

An additional issue concerns the extent to which the results might be generalized beyond the sample. The comparisons with withdrawing subjects suggest that the expatriates were representative of the experimentally accessible sample. The expatriates’ demographic characteristics are also typical of other empirical studies within AVI (e.g. Brook et al., 2007), and in similar agencies (e.g. Peace Corps, 2011), suggesting sound ‘population validity.’ The generalizability to the broader expatriate community is likely constrained by two factors. Firstly, as outlined above, the purpose of the EDP’s role is organizational development. Given research suggesting that expatriates with objectives linked to their professional development report greater personal change (Shay and Baack, 2004), it may be that the changes are even more pronounced in this group. Secondly, EDPs generally relocate across large cultural distances, and so the different cultural milieu may provide a ‘blow to the head’ (Gregersen et al., 1998: 28) that reshapes their cognitive frames in different ways to the more modest cultural chasm traversed by some expatriates. Future studies might consider including a third comparison group: expatriates undertaking a less ‘extreme’ form of expatriate assignment. Having said that, distinctions between the EDPs and ‘mainstream’ expatriates should not be overstated; for instance, like other expatriates, the motivations of EDPs are complex, and frequently include career development outcomes, even if their roles do not (Hustinx and Lammertyn, 2003). Like corporate expatriates, they also make up a pool of skilled globally mobile workers that are highly sought after by knowledge-intensive organizations from all sectors (Cook and Jackson, 2006).

sec.title: Practical implications
sec.p: The study’s results are likely of interest to both individual expatriates and the organizations that recruit and support them. While organizations often use expatriate assignments to develop human capital (e.g. Dickmann and Doherty, 2008), limited research has measured or examined cognitive changes experienced by expatriates. The objective, quantifiable changes reported here, therefore, provide some initial empirical evidence that may make expatriate assignments more attractive to individuals wishing to enhance their creative-thinking abilities, and thus reduce the extent to which firms rely on financial incentives to encourage staff to expatriate.

The issue of how organizations might refine their expatriate management processes to support the growth in creative-thinking abilities of expatriates could extend to all stages of the expatriate lifecycle. For instance, while cross-cultural training programs have limited influence on adjustment patterns (Hechanova et al., 2003), pre-departure training that raises expatriates’ awareness of existing cognitive frameworks and the role that these play during adaptation, or that teaches processes for observing and integrating relevant new ideas, may facilitate or expedite the development of ideational fluency, elaboration, and/or originality capabilities (e.g. Boyacigiller et al., 2004). Similarly, firms may design repatriation procedures and/or follow-up placements that recognize and exploit the cognitive flexibility of their staff as a way to retain both the expatriate and the creative dividends that they accrue (Amabile and Khaire, 2008). The findings also raise questions for the ways in which organizations might structure expatriate assignments. For instance, do short-term postings contribute sufficiently to the deculturation process to influence cognitive flexibility, or is a minimum duration required? How might firms replicate the ‘benefits’ of expatriation in domestic contexts through, for example, the use of cross-cultural teams, or environments that temporarily simulate uncertainty in ways that can challenge employees’ habitual schemas? And what might individual expatriates or organizations do to limit or prevent any amortization of creative-thinking abilities after repatriation?

Conversely, some firms or individuals may be more concerned with the short-term instability created by cognitive changes, rather than the potential benefits. Research of corporate, mainly managerial, expatriate development has tended to focus on incremental learning outcomes that are role- and organization-specific (Harvey and Novicevic, 2006), and organizations using expatriates to perform control functions may view significant cognitive changes as (potentially) contributing to agency costs, repatriation turnover, or even placement failure. Consequently, the value of the assignment to the expatriates’ development must be tempered against contextual and organizational factors. While this is a legitimate concern, even those individuals or firms not seeking professional development would be wise to understand, and where necessary plan for, the cognitive changes that expatriates may undergo.

bio.p: Anthony Fee is a Lecturer in International Business at the University of Technology Sydney, Australia. He was formerly a Lecturer at the University of Sydney, Australia. His research focuses on expatriate development and training, particularly self-initiated expatriates within the development and NGO sectors. His work has been published in international conference proceedings, edited books, and international journals, including International Journal of Human Resource Management, Journal of World Business, and Asia Pacific Journal of Human Resources.

Sidney J Gray is Professor of International Business and Co-Director of the Innovation and Entrepreneurship Research Group at the University of Sydney, Australia. He was formerly a Professor at the University of New South Wales, Australia, Warwick Business School, UK and the University of Glasgow, UK. His research interests include managing across cultures and expatriate management, internationalization processes and business performance, and international corporate governance and transparency. He is currently on the editorial boards of Journal of International Business Studies and Management International Review and his work has been published in these and other journals such as International Journal of Human Resource Management, Corporate Governance: An International Review, and Journal of Accounting Research.
